reviewText: I have to chuckle when I see a review of this saying its full of twists and turns.  In fact, its 100% predictable and can be explained in one sentence..."Paralyzed man imagines fantasy where he is private dectective".  Care to guess the "trick" ending?Anyhow its a low budget movie where everything is just a bit off.  The characters dress and talk, more or less for the 1940s.  But they drive a 1959 Caddy.  And when the detective enters the blond's house, there's a modern motion detector for the burglar alarm, right over his head.  Whoops.But its not terrible.  BillyBob is in fine form and the others would probably be fine too if the script was better.  The blond is built but you won't mistake her for Lana Turner.So, if you want to see Film Noir, for heaven's sake, get Out Of The Past.  If for some reason you want a modern slant, try Cast A Deadly Spell or Witch Hunt.  But if you've already seen these and want to see some actors smoking a lot of cigarettes and trying very hard to be cool, its fairly entertaining.
summary: Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid without the humor.

reviewText: Odd little art-house film that some so-called astute reviewers here seem to be weighing against 'The Maltese Falcon'. People, if Keanu Reeves was in this you'd probably be lapping it up. Kidding. Sort of. In it Richard (Metzler) plays a spine cancer victim with a used tire business, an annoying sister, a couple of loyal employees, and one friend (John Ritter) who still finds time to see him. It's assumed that Richard, somewhat wealthy & a bit of a golden boy, had friends and hangers on coming out of the woodwork before he became ill. He begins using a system of mind projection that his New Age pal Ritter sells him on, and between that and 'The Late Late Show' begins to see himself as a 1940's gumshoe. People may notice props or cars might be a little or way off, but remember, within the context we're dealing with Richard's limited knowledge of these things, so if they were perfect, to me that would constitute a more noticeable flaw in the film. Forgive my cognition. Okay, here are the good things. John Ritter. Ritter had passed away by the time I saw this, and his character seemed so concerned, self effacing and yes, Ritter-ish, that it made his performance seem almost a victory lap for the fine work he'd done during his career. Kay Lenz (from the Patridge Family?!) was acceptably saucy and was somehow able to get across that although quite shallow, she loved and wanted to help her brother. She's quite a good actress. Victor Love & Norma Maldonado as the nurse/therapist and housekeeper were both very fine. The Black Chinaman thing was odd, but fun. Andrea Thompson was quite good as the intriguing femme fatale. That aside, let me say, "Whooooooo!!". I miss the 90's, they don't build 'em like that anymore. Lovely woman, and an exceptional actress. I've never seen her anywhere else! She's a big plus for the movie. And of course there's Billy Bob Thorton, doing a great character piece as Lenz's new boyfriend with a back injury lawsuit against a bar. I miss him doing "real" characters instead of foul-mouthed idiots in wigs. And Van Johnson's "Gun, Car, .." title song was mesmerizing, as was she. The bad. Obvious the budget was nearly non existent. And I'd have to add Metzler. He was often quite affecting, but overall not actor enough to pull it off. He's a good actor certainly, but someone with more gravity -- say, Kevin Costner, could've done more with the part. But I think this was Metzler's "baby" -- I had thought he directed it, but apparently he did not. The film ends in a hopeful note, and I remember it cheering me greatly about a decade ago. I'm giving it five stars! For me it did what it set out to do, and I could name some big budget critically lauded films I don't like nearly as well.
summary: A Gun, a Car, a Hottie, a Billy Bob, a John Ritter, and a Good Film
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie, featuring scenes in black and white and colo[u]r, is part detective story, part inner struggle, for the man who spends his time in a wheelchair, griping about life.  That is, until his friend (played by the late John Ritter) tells him about a means of creating a fantasy life for himself.  He does that, which is what leads to the "detective" part of the story.  He (Metzler) plays a detective named "Stone", and he's visited by a blonde; played by the stunning looking Andrea Thompson (who reveals quite a bit more than she did on NYPD Blue-WOW! [unfortunately, the scene is in black and white, but she still looks good, in any case]).  Kay Lenz, who still has it "going on", and has held up well body wise, if she's not had anything done, as his whiny sister is good.  With Billy Bob Thornton and the aforementioned late Mr. Ritter [who all play dual roles] it's not too bad.  Not a classic but not bad [especially if you want to see what Ms. Thompson was hiding under those "detective" clothes on NYPD Blue].  Features include the theatrical trailer and credits and a synopsis of the story.  [Problem is the "cast" part only mentions the three actors, Thornton, Metzler, and Ritter.]  Still a fairly reasonable movie, for the most part.  (I got it for cheap, but I won't say where, as it would be competition for Amazon.)
summary: Not too bad, Thompson's a knockout; Lenz holds up well
Title: N/A

reviewText: The talents of Billy Bob Thornton, Kay Lenz, John Ritter and Andrea Thompson aren't enough to salvage this crass and unimaginative drivel about Richard (Jim Metzler), a man with spinal cancer who discovers he can escape  the pain for awhile through the use of "Objectification therapy."  By  submerging himself into what is essentially a deep daydream, he is able to  transport himself into an imaginary, black-and-white film noir world in  which he is a Private Eye named Rick Stone.  Apparently, director Stefani  Ames had a limited shooting schedule on this film; too many scenes play  like they were done in a single take with no rehearsal, as if the actors  came away from the table after the initial cold reading with the cameras  already rolling.  Though obviously attempting to evoke the B-movies of the  forties, the dialogue is laughably bad, especially in the black-and-white  segments.  Metzler's character, a cancer victim no less, is inexplicably  unsympathetic, and Kay Lenz will not be getting a career boost from her  turn as Richard's shrewish sister, "Peep."  Billy Bob Thornton and John  Ritter will always have "Sling Blade," and at least Andrea Thompson was  lucky enough to escape this sort of fare for a spot on TV's "NYPD Blue."  The unfortunates rounding out the supporting cast include Victor Love,  Norma Maldonado and Paula Marshall.  The best thing that can be said about  this film is that it makes one appreciate a really good movie.  Where's  Bogart or Mitchum when you need them?
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 1997 film has many scenes that alternate between color and black-and-white (B&W). The premise of the movie is that a person with the reality (i.e., in color) of spinal cancer can obtain significant relief by a complete delving into a world of fantasy (in B&W), which takes place in a 1957 film-noir setting. As a big fan of the black-and-white film-noir movies of the 1940s and 1950s, I found this film quite appealing. Although it probably was not meant this way, the film is an effective parody of the film-noir genre, complete with its stylized settings and simplistic dialog. The B&W components are well photographed with noir motifs (the classic venation blind effect, for instance), and the color scenes segue effectively and often cleverly into the B&W scenes, such as when hands on the wheel of a wheel chair transition into hands on the steering wheel of a car. Many events (as the tossing of a  fortune cookie), lines, and of course characters from the color parts are reused in the B&W parts. In the at times tedious color part concerned with the modern world the unsympathetic cancer victim and his obnoxious sister and her boyfriend, who have some laughable lines, are admittedly quite off-putting. Neither color part nor B&W part stands alone, but the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The jazz score of the movie is very appealing.
Title: N/A
